chapter.htmlHeader: Scenario: Jaundice in the newborn
chapter.summary: Covers the assessment of a neonate with jaundice and their management, including when to refer to secondary care.
chapter.htmlStringContent: From birth to 1 months.

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: Assessment of neonatal jaundice
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Review the baby's Personal Child Health Record and hospital birth discharge documentation and talk to the parent or carer to determine if there are features that can influence the development of significant hyperbilirubinaemia. Be aware of:
    • Obstetric history (including the mother's Rhesus status and blood group if known) and the baby's gestational age at birth.
    • Age at onset and duration of jaundice.
    • Feeding history (type of feeding and whether there have been any problems with adequate intake).
    • Number of wet or dirty nappies in a day (to assess the state of hydration). Also specifically ask about the presence of dark urine and/or pale stools.
    • Signs of illness (for example lethargy, fever, vomiting, significant weight loss, irritability).
    • Family history of relevant conditions — for example significant haemolysis (including glucose-6-phosphate-dehydrogenase deficiency). Ask whether any siblings or close family members have required hospital treatment such as phototherapy or exchange blood transfusion for neonatal jaundice.
  • Examine the neonate to assess for:
    • Any signs of illness, including fever.
    • Appropriate weight gain (compared with previous measurements if available).
    • Evidence of bruising (for example cephalhaematoma following ventouse delivery).
  • Evaluate the extent of jaundice.
    • Jaundice in the neonate spreads from the head downwards with increasing severity (cephalocaudal progression).
    • In some cases, only the head may appear jaundiced.
    • However, be aware that a visual assessment alone is not a reliable indicator of bilirubin level and therefore should not be used to estimate the severity of jaundice.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on assessment of neonatal jaundice are largely based on expert opinion in the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence guideline Jaundice in newborn babies under 28 days [NICE, 2016] and are also consistent with the recommendations within the Queensland Maternity and Neonatal Clinical Guideline Neonatal jaundice [Queensland Health, 2019].

Features in the history and examination
  • The information on features that can influence the risk of significant hyperbilirubinaemia is largely based on expert opinion in the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence guideline Jaundice in newborn babies under 28 days [NICE, 2016], the Queensland Maternity and Neonatal Clinical Guideline Neonatal jaundice [Queensland Health, 2019], and within a review article Understanding and managing breast milk jaundice [Preer, 2011]. The suggestion to enquire about family members requiring admission to hospital for the treatment of neonatal jaundice is based on the expert opinion of previous reviewers of this CKS topic.
  • NICE states that 'There is consistent evidence from good-quality studies to show that four factors are independently associated with an increased risk of hyperbilirubinaemia — gestational age < 38 weeks, jaundice within 24 hours of birth, increase in severity of clinically apparent jaundice, and intention to breastfeed exclusively' [National Collaborating Centre for Women's and Children's Health, 2010].
Evaluation of extent of jaundice
  • Visual inspection is known to be inaccurate compared with transcutaneous or serum bilirubin measurements [National Collaborating Centre for Women's and Children's Health, 2010]. Expert opinion in the Queensland Maternity and Neonatal Clinical Guideline Neonatal jaundice states that visual estimation can lead to errors, especially if the baby has a darker skin tone [Queensland Health, 2019]. The NICE guideline development group (GDG) reviewed the available evidence and found that, in term babies, parents and healthcare professionals are able to recognize jaundice, but not assess its severity clinically [National Collaborating Centre for Women's and Children's Health, 2010].
  • Management should therefore not be solely guided by the findings of a visual assessment. For more information, see the section on Management.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Management of neonatal jaundice
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Arrange emergency admission (via 999 ambulance) if there is jaundice with features of bilirubin encephalopathy (for example atypical sleepiness, poor feeding, irritability, vomiting, hypotonia followed by hypertonia).
  • Arrange urgent admission to a neonatal or paediatric unit (depending on local arrangements) within 2 hours if jaundice first appears at less than 24 hours of age.
  • Arrange urgent admission to a neonatal or paediatric unit (depending on local arrangements) as soon as possible and to be seen within 6 hours (using clinical judgement regarding more urgent referral or admission) if:
    • Jaundice first appears at more than 7 days of age.
    • The neonate is unwell (for example, lethargy, fever, vomiting, irritability).
    • Gestational age is of less than 35 weeks.
    • Prolonged jaundice is suspected — that is a gestational age of less than 37 weeks with more than 21 days of jaundice; or a gestational age of 37 weeks or more with more than 14 days of jaundice.
    • There are feeding problems and/or concerns about weight, particularly in breastfed infants.
    • Pale stools and dark urine are noted.
  • For all other jaundiced neonates:
    • If transcutaneous bilirubin measurements are available in primary care, record the level within 6 hours and manage according to local protocols.
    • If transcutaneous bilirubin measurements are unavailable in primary care, refer to a neonatal or paediatric unit (depending on local arrangements) for measurement of a serum bilirubin level within 6 hours. Do not rely on visual assessment of jaundice to guide management.
  • Reassure parents and carers that:
    • Neonatal jaundice is common and is usually transient and harmless.
    • Breastfeeding can usually continue.
      • Encourage breastfeeding mothers to breastfeed frequently (for example every 3 hours) and to wake the baby for feeds. Refer for breastfeeding support if necessary. Advise that supplementing with water or formula milk is usually not recommended. For more information, see the CKS topic on Breastfeeding problems.
  • Advise on additional sources of information and support including:
    • NICE neonatal jaundice parent information factsheet (https://www.nice.org.uk/guidance/cg98/ifp/chapter/about-this-information).
    • Bliss, a special care baby charity (www.bliss.org.uk).
    • The Breastfeeding Network (www.breastfeedingnetwork.org.uk).
    • Children's Liver Disease Foundation (www.childliverdisease.org).
    • La Leche League (www.laleche.org.uk).
    • National Childbirth Trust (www.nct.org.uk).

subChapters.htmlHeader: Secondary care investigations and management
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
•  In secondary care, serum bilirubin levels are usually measured in order to confirm the diagnosis and guide treatment. Neonates with significant jaundice will have investigations to determine any underlying causes, which may include:
    • Full blood count and blood film — a high or low white blood cell count or thrombocytopaenia can suggest sepsis; a haematocrit of less than 45% can suggest haemolytic anaemia; an increased reticulocyte count suggests haemolysis; a peripheral blood film may show evidence of haemolysis.
    • Blood group (mother and baby) — ABO incompatibility is suggested by a mother with blood group O and a baby with group A or B. Rhesus incompatibility is suggested if the mother is Rhesus negative and her baby is Rhesus positive.
    • DAT (Coombs' test) — used to diagnose ABO or Rhesus isoimmunization.
    • Liver function tests — in congenital infection, liver enzymes may be increased.
    • Blood glucose-6-phosphate-dehydrogenase (G6PD) levels, taking into account ethnic origin — to check for G6PD deficiency.
    • Microbiological cultures of blood, urine, and/or cerebrospinal fluid (if infection is suspected) — to look for a source of sepsis.
  • The choice of treatment in secondary care will depend on a number of factors, including the underlying cause of the jaundice. Options include:
    • No treatment — this may be appropriate for well neonates with physiological or breastmilk jaundice and a bilirubin level below the treatment threshold.
    • Treatment of any underlying illness (such as infection).
    • Phototherapy — absorption of light through the skin converts unconjugated bilirubin into products that are more easily excretable in the stool and urine.
    • Exchange transfusion — indicated if the baby has signs of bilirubin encephalopathy and considered if the risk of kernicterus is high or jaundice is not responding to phototherapy.
    • Early surgical treatment — required for conditions such as biliary atresia.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on management of neonatal jaundice are largely based on expert opinion in the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) guideline Jaundice in newborn babies under 28 days [NICE, 2016], the full NICE guideline Neonatal jaundice on which this was based [National Collaborating Centre for Women's and Children's Health, 2010], and are also consistent with the recommendations within the Queensland Maternity and Neonatal Clinical Guideline Neonatal jaundice [Queensland Health, 2019].

Emergency referral if encephalopathy suspected
  • CKS has pragmatically recommended emergency referral, on the grounds that bilirubin encephalopathy is a medical emergency and babies showing signs of neurological dysfunction need urgent assessment and treatment to minimize the risk of serious sequelae. A guideline from NICE Neonatal jaundice advises using a double volume exchange transfusion to treat babies with clinical features and signs of acute bilirubin encephalopathy [National Collaborating Centre for Women's and Children's Health, 2010], and an Australian guideline Neonatal jaundice also recommends this on an urgent basis [Queensland Health, 2019].
  • The examples of features suggestive of bilirubin encephalopathy are based on information within the Queensland Maternity and Neonatal Clinical Guideline Neonatal jaundice [Queensland Health, 2019] and the expert opinion of a previous reviewer of this CKS topic.
Urgent admission 
  • The NICE guideline Jaundice in newborn babies under 28 days recommends urgently measuring and recording the serum bilirubin level within 2 hours (and medically reviewing within 6 hours) for all babies with suspected or obvious jaundice in the first 24 hours of life [NICE, 2016].
  • The additional criteria for consideration of urgent admission are based on expert opinion of the risk factors for significant hyperbilirubinaemia and the clinical features of serious underlying causes for jaundice in the NICE guideline Jaundice in newborn babies under 28 days [NICE, 2016], the Queensland Maternity and Neonatal Clinical Guideline Neonatal jaundice [Queensland Health, 2019], and the BMJ Best Practice guideline Neonatal jaundice [BMJ Best Practice, 2020].
Measurement of bilirubin within 6 hours for other specific groups
  • NICE states that the bilirubin level should be measured urgently within 6 hours in all babies more than 24 hours old with suspected or obvious jaundice [NICE, 2016].
Jaundice first appearing at more than 7 days of age
  • The NICE guideline Postnatal care up to 8 weeks after birth recommends, on the basis of expert opinion, that if jaundice first develops after 7 days and a cause has not already been identified the baby should be urgently evaluated [NICE, 2015]. Physiological and breastmilk jaundice usually appear within the first week of life [National Collaborating Centre for Women's and Children's Health, 2010; Queensland Health, 2019].
Unwell babies
  • The NICE guideline Postnatal care up to 8 weeks after birth recommends measuring a serum bilirubin level if a baby is significantly jaundiced or appears unwell [NICE, 2015]. CKS has pragmatically recommended referral of unwell babies with jaundice as the resources and expertise to perform the investigations necessary to exclude underlying conditions and guide treatment are unlikely to be available in primary care.
Gestational age less than 35 weeks 
  • The NICE guideline Jaundice in newborn babies under 28 days [NICE, 2016] recommends using a transcutaneous bilirubinometer to measure the bilirubin level in babies with a gestational age of 35 weeks or more, but states that serum bilirubin measurement should be used in babies less than 35 weeks gestational age.
  • The opinion of the guideline development group was also that babies at less than 35 weeks gestation are more vulnerable than term babies to kernicterus at relatively low levels of bilirubin and therefore need more accurate testing, and that the evidence for accuracy of transcutaneous bilirubinometers in babies at less than 35 weeks gestation is unclear.
  • CKS therefore recommends that babies born at less than 35 weeks gestation require referral to secondary care to assess their serum bilirubin level.
Prolonged jaundice
  • Referral of babies with prolonged jaundice is recommended on the basis of expert opinion within the NICE guideline Jaundice in newborn babies under 28 days [NICE, 2016]. This states that babies with prolonged jaundice (gestational age of 37 weeks or more with jaundice lasting more than 14 days; or babies with a gestational age of less than 37 weeks and jaundice lasting more than 21 days) should have a number of tests to exclude underlying causes (including conjugated bilirubin level, full blood count, blood group determination and DAT [Coombs' test], urine culture, and metabolic screening).
Poor feeding and concerns about weight
  • This recommendation is based on expert opinion that poor feeding, dehydration, and a reduction in caloric intake below the optimal intake for age can exacerbate jaundice in neonates [Barrington, 2007; Academy of Breastfeeding Medicine, 2017; Queensland Health, 2019; BMJ Best Practice, 2020].
  • Expert opinion suggests that jaundice in a breastfed infant who is not feeding well is potentially serious as it can lead to dehydration, malnutrition, and high bilirubin levels, increasing the risk of bilirubin encephalopathy. Inadequate intake of breastmilk can cause a reduction in stool output, leading to increased resorption of bilirubin from the gut [Preer, 2011].
Pale stools and dark urine
  • The recommendation to refer is based on expert opinion that pale stools and dark urine can be an indicator of liver disease such as biliary atresia where bile is not excreted from the liver and bile duct into the intestine [Queensland Health, 2019].
Use of a transcutaneous bilirubinometer 
  • NICE recommends that transcutaneous bilirubin measurement is suitable for babies over 24 hours old and with a gestational age of 35 weeks or more [NICE, 2016]. This is based on evidence that transcutaneous bilirubinometer measurements are adequately accurate in term babies below treatment levels (bilirubin less than 250 micromol/L) and the guideline development group's opinion that the evidence for accuracy of transcutaneous bilirubinometers in babies at less than 35 weeks gestation is unclear [National Collaborating Centre for Women's and Children's Health, 2010].
  • It is recommended that serum bilirubin should be measured if a transcutaneous bilirubinometer is not available [NICE, 2016]. CKS is aware that transcutaneous bilirubinometers are not always available in the community and has therefore recommended referral to secondary care for measurement of serum bilirubin level if this is the case. Expert opinion from previous reviewers of this CKS topic supports this, with reviewers emphasizing the inaccuracy of visual assessment of jaundice and warning of its potential to underestimate the serum bilirubin level.
  • NICE also recommends that if a transcutaneous bilirubinometer measurement indicates a bilirubin level greater than 250 micromol/litre, serum bilirubin should be measured to check the result [NICE, 2016].
Reassurance and advice
  • NICE states that parents and carers should be offered verbal and written advice that is tailored to their needs and concerns, with care taken to avoid unnecessary anxiety [NICE, 2016]. CKS has therefore provided links to various reputable sources of information about jaundice, breastfeeding, and neonatal care.
Secondary care investigations and management
  • The information on potential investigations and management strategies for neonatal jaundice in secondary care is based on expert opinion in the NICE guideline Jaundice in newborn babies under 28 days [NICE, 2016], the Queensland Maternity and Neonatal Clinical Guideline Neonatal jaundice [Queensland Health, 2019], the BMJ Best Practice guideline Neonatal jaundice [BMJ Best Practice, 2020], and the review articles Understanding and managing breast milk jaundice [Preer, 2011] and Evaluation and treatment of neonatal hyperbilirubinemia [Muchowski, 2014].
